How beautiful are thy feet with shoes, O prince's daughter! the joints of thy thighs <FI>are<Fi> like jewels, the work of the hands of a cunning workman.
Thy navel <FI>is like<Fi> a round goblet, <FI>which<Fi> wanteth not liquor: thy belly <FI>is like<Fi> an heap of wheat set about with lilies.<RF>liquor: Heb. mixture<Rf>
Thy two breasts <FI>are<Fi> like two young roes <FI>that are<Fi> twins.
Thy neck <FI>is<Fi> as a tower of ivory; thine eyes <FI>like<Fi> the fishpools in Heshbon, by the gate of Bathrabbim: thy nose <FI>is<Fi> as the tower of Lebanon which looketh toward Damascus.
Thine head upon thee <FI>is<Fi> like Carmel, and the hair of thine head like purple; the king <FI>is<Fi> held in the galleries.<RF>Carmel: or, crimson<Rf><RF>held: Heb. bound<Rf>
How fair and how pleasant art thou, O love, for delights!
This thy stature is like to a palm tree, and thy breasts to clusters <FI>of grapes<Fi>.
I said, I will go up to the palm tree, I will take hold of the boughs thereof: now also thy breasts shall be as clusters of the vine, and the smell of thy nose like apples;

And the roof of thy mouth like the best wine for my beloved, that goeth <FI>down<Fi> sweetly, causing the lips of those that are asleep to speak.<RF>sweetly: Heb. straightly<Rf><RF>of thoseâ€¦: or, of the ancient<Rf><CM>
I <FI>am<Fi> my beloved's, and his desire <FI>is<Fi> toward me.
Come, my beloved, let us go forth into the field; let us lodge in the villages.

Let us get up early to the vineyards; let us see if the vine flourish, <FI>whether<Fi> the tender grape appear, <FI>and<Fi> the pomegranates bud forth: there will I give thee my loves.<RF>appear: Heb. open<Rf>
The mandrakes give a smell, and at our gates <FI>are<Fi> all manner of pleasant <FI>fruits<Fi>, new and old, <FI>which<Fi> I have laid up for thee, O my beloved.<CM>
